docs.title: Welcome to goldilock
docs.text:
A basic python package

  • Free software: MIT license
  • Documentation: https://NandhiniKRC.github.io/goldilock

docs.title: common module
docs.text: The common module contains common functions and classes used by the other modules.

docs.title: hello_world()
docs.text:
Prints "Hello World!" to the console.

Source code in goldilock/common.py 
def hello_world():
"""Prints "Hello World!" to the console.
    """
    print("Hello World!")

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/NandhiniKRC/goldilock/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with bug and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with enhancement and help wanted is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: goldilock could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official goldilock docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/NandhiniKRC/goldilock/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here's how to set up goldilock for local development.

  1. Fork the goldilock repo on GitHub.

  2. Clone your fork locally:

    $ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/goldilock.git

  3. Install your local copy into a virtualenv. Assuming you have virtualenvwrapper installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:

    $ mkvirtualenv goldilock
$ cd goldilock/
$ python setup.py develop

  4. Create a branch for local development:

    $ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

    Now you can make your changes locally.

  5. When you're done making changes, check that your changes pass flake8 and the tests, including testing other Python versions with tox:

    $ flake8 goldilock tests
$ python setup.py test or pytest
$ tox

    To get flake8 and tox, just pip install them into your virtualenv.

  6. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:

    $ git add .
$ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
$ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

  7. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.rst.
  3. The pull request should work for Python 3.5, 3.6, 3.7 and 3.8, and for PyPy. Check https://github.com/NandhiniKRC/goldilock/pull_requests and make sure that the tests pass for all supported Python versions.

docs.title: goldilock module
docs.text: Main module.

docs.title: generate_random_string(length, upper=False, digits=False, punctuation=False)
docs.text:
This function generates a random string of a given length.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default length int

The length of the string to generate. Defaults to 10.

required upper bool

Whether to use uppercase letters or not. Defaults to False.

False digits bool

Whether to use digits or not. Defaults to False.

False punctuation bool

Whether to use punctuations or not. Defaults to False.

False

Returns:

Type Description str

The string of specified length generated randomly

Source code in goldilock/goldilock.py 
def generate_random_string(length, upper = False, digits = False, punctuation = False):
"""This function generates a random string of a given length.

    Args:
        length (int, optional): The length of the string to generate. Defaults to 10.
        upper (bool, optional): Whether to use uppercase letters or not. Defaults to False.
        digits (bool, optional): Whether to use digits or not. Defaults to False.
        punctuation (bool, optional): Whether to use punctuations or not. Defaults to False.

    Returns:
        str: The string of specified length generated randomly
    """    
    letters = string.ascii_lowercase
    if upper:
        letters += string.ascii_uppercase

    if punctuation:
        letters += string.punctuation

    if digits:
        letters += string.digits

    print(letters)
    return ''.join(random.choice(letters) for i in range(length))

docs.title: Stable release
docs.text:
To install goldilock, run this command in your terminal:

pip install goldilock

This is the preferred method to install goldilock, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

If you don't have pip installed, this Python installation guide can guide you through the process.

docs.title: From sources
docs.text:
To install goldilock from sources, run this command in your terminal:

pip install git+https://github.com/NandhiniKRC/goldilock

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
To use goldilock in a project:

import goldilock
